p: The prevalence of diarrhoeal diseases in developing countries is high and is responsible for an estimated 7% of all deaths in developing countries, second only to malnutrition ( 27). It also impairs productivity at work and accounts for many lost work days. Diarrhoeal diseases are strongly linked to poor hygiene and sanitation practices, and lack of infrastructure, especially the contamination of food and water supplies through unregulated disposal of human excreta. Direct contact with an infected person is also an important disease transmission route. Environmental transmission is less common as many of these microorganisms are not robust enough to survive for long outside the host ( 28). However, future climate change is likely to generate circumstances and events that markedly increase the transmission of disease.
